awd_titl_txt: FRG: Collaborative Research: Algebraic Geometry and Singularities in Positive and Mixed Characteristic
awd_abstract_narration:
Algebraic Geometry studies algebraic varieties which are geometric objects defined by polynomial equations. One of the most natural problems in this area is to understand the singularities that naturally occur when considering algebraic varieties and how these singularities influence the global geometry of algebraic varieties. In recent years there have been a number of breakthroughs, especially in the case where we consider solutions over the complex numbers. At the same time new techniques and approaches have emerged for studying solutions in positive and mixed characteristics. The primary goal of this collaborative project is to advance and unify these ideas to further understand and solve some of the most challenging programs in both local and global algebraic geometry. In addition the project provides research training opportunities for graduate students.
 
The PIs will investigate singularities in positive and mixed characteristics by using a variety of techniques including those arising from the minimal model program, from the theory of F-singularities, and from Scholze's work on perfectoid algebras and spaces. The PIs will also organize workshops, a summer school and a conference, aimed at training young researchers in this area, disseminating recent results and facilitating further advances and breakthroughs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has supported the research of 2 full professors (K. Schwede and C. Hacon) and the training of about 20 graduate students and Post Docs at the University of Utah as well as collaborations with researchers from the University of Michigan Ann Arbor, Purdue, Univ. of Washington, Princeton University and the IAS. This research has resulted in over 30 research publications in algebraic geometry. The research funded by this project has been centered around the areas of Birational Geometry and Singularities In Zero, Positive and Mixed Characteristics. Some of the highlights of this project include the following papers:

-- On the four dimensional minimal model program for Kahler varieties, by Omprokash Das, Christopher Hacon, Mihai Paun. Adv. Math. 443 (2024), No. 109615, 68 pp. This paper establishes the (relative)  minimal model program for projective morphisms of Kahler varieties and for effective 4-fold klt Kahler pairs.

-- Globally +-regular varieties and the minimal model program for threefolds in mixed characteristic. Bhargav Bhatt, Linquan Ma, Zsolt Patakfalvi, Karl Schwede, Kevin Tucker, Joe Waldron, Jakub Witaszek. Publ. Math. Inst. Hautes Études Sci.138(2023), 69-227. This paper establishes the minimal model program for arithmetic threefolds whose residue characteristics are greater than five and generalizes the theory of global-regularity to mixed characteristic.

-- Existence of flips for generalized lc pairs, Christopher Hacon and Jihao Liu, Cambridge Journal of Mathematics Volume 11, Number 4, 795–828, 2023. This paper establishes the minimal model program for generalized log canonical pairs.

The results obtained have further been disseminated at conferences, workshops, Algebraic Geometry seminars and colloquia in the US and internationally.

The PI's also organized a Virtual Special Month at the University of Utah May 17 - June 11th, 2021, a Learning Workshop and Conference on Algebraic Geometry and Singularities at the University of Washington, June 20 - June 26, 2022, and a Special month at the University of Michigan May 8th - June 2nd, 2023. These activities were extremely well attended by students, postdocs and faculty alike. These activities included mini-courses and workshops aimed at training graduate students in new active areas of research as well as lectures on cutting edge research and provided ample time for discussions and collaborations on new research projects.
